Detailed Description

ASr - File search and replace.

ASr searches the text in a set of text files for a match with a regular expression. The matched text is replaced with a a replace string. After an instance of ASr is declared, the replace method carries out the search and replace operation. The search starts in the folder specified by the irPath argument. irPath may be relative or absolute.

See also:
replace()
Notes:
  1. cFilters is a list of wildcard expressions (e.g., *.txt). Only files that match one or more of these wildcard expressions is included in the search.
  2. cRegExp is a QT regular expression. See the QT documentation for QRegExp for more details.

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

ASr::ASr (  const QString &  irSearch,
const QString &  irReplace,
const QString &  irFiles,
bool  iRecurse
) 
 

ASr implements a text file search and replace.

The constructor initializes the private class properties.

Parameters:
irSearch The regular expression that is to be matched by the text in the file. See note below.
irReplace The string that replaces the matched text. See note below.
irFiles Zero or more wildcard expressions that identify the files to be included in the search
iRecurse Iff true, all subdirectories are included in the search.
See also:
replace()
Notes:
  1. irSearch patterns obey the QT regular expression conventions. Consult the QT documentation for details.
  2. If irReplace is empty, replace deletes all matching strings.
  3. In irReplace \1 matches the portion of the regular expression enclosed in first set of parentheses. \2 matches the second set of parentheses and so on.
  4. If irReplace is just \0, then replace just searches without performing a replace.
  5. If irFiles is empty, search defaults to all files. Example: sr*.cpp
  6. If Recurse is true all subdirectories are included in the search.
Regular Expressions.
The following characters have special meaning in a regular expression. If you wish to include the character itself in a search string, prepend a backslash to the character. 
 \ Backslash. Used to escape other characters
 ^ If first char. Denotes beg-of-text. Also used as not operator inside brackets.
 $ If last char. Denotes end-of-text
 () Parentheses. Group subexpressions into one expression.
 . Dot. Matches any character
 * Asterisk. Match zero or more of previous expression.
 + Plus. Match one or more of previous expression.
 ? Question Mark. Matches zero or one of the previous expression.
 {} Braces. Enclose minimum/maximum expression counts.
 [] Brackets. Used to denote a range of characters
 -  Dash. Range separator inside brackets

ASr::~ASr (   ) 
 

ASr destructor.

On destruction of an instance of ASr, the destructor for each private variable is automatically invoked.

Member Function Documentation

int ASr::replace (  const QString &  irPath  ) 
 

replaces the text that matches cSearch with cReplace in every file that matches one of the filters.

replace extracts the names of the files in the directory specifed by irPath that match one or more of the wildcard strings in cFilters. For example, if irPath is "test" and cFilters is *.txt, then all of the .txt files in the test subdirectory are searched.

The regular expresssion cSearch is applied to the text in the file. Each matching string is replaced by the string cReplace. If a portion of the regular expression is enclosed in parentheses, that portion of the matched string is substituted for \1 in the replace string. For example if cSearch is "(\\w+)=(\w+)and cReplace is "\1&\2" then every pair of words separated by an equal sign are replaced by the same words separated by an ampersand.

Args:
Parameters:
irPath The root directory of the search.
See also:
ASr()
Notes:
  1. The path may be relative or absolute.
  2. If irPath is empty search starts at the current working directory.
  3. The search parameters are logged at the beginning of every search-replace.
  4. The name of every matching file and the number of matches for the file are also logged. PENDING - extract end() iterator from loop.
